quoteFirst: “He says we should have been over Webster at
quoteLast: and that we’re eight minutes late,” he repeated.
title: The Airship Boys' Ocean Flyer; Or, New York to London in Twelve Hours
author: Sayler, H. L. (Harry Lincoln), 1863-1913; Riesenberg, Sidney H., 1885-1971 [Illustrator]

quoteFirst: But in this latitude, on the former date, the star rises at 5:43 a. m., one hour and five minutes _after_, and on the latter date at
quoteLast: , two hours and twenty minutes _before_ sunrise. Others fix the time from July 3rd to August 11th (forty days), without any respect to the rising of _Sirius_, which on the former date appears above our horizon at 6:51 a. m.
title: The Chautauquan, Vol. 04, July 1884, No. 10
author: Chautauqua Literary and Scientific Circle; Chautauqua Institution; Flood, Theodore L., 1842- [Editor]

quoteLast: , June 4; one that has had Thoughts and all my little Imperfections. Sir, come to me immediately, or I shall determine what may perhaps not be very pleasing to you.

quoteFirst: If you see one of the Hoffs leave the house, don’t merely report to me that the old man or the young man left the house about three o’clock. That won’t do at all. I want to know the exact time. Was it
quoteLast: or eleven minutes after three? I must know what direction he went, if he was alone, how long he was absent, where he went, what he did, to whom he talked. Here in my office I take your reports, Carter’s reports, a dozen other reports, and study them together.
title: The Apartment Next Door
author: Johnston, William, 1871-1929

quoteLast: , and not a sign of them!" exclaimed Joan Mardle, with the explosive articulation of one who cannot any longer hold back a truth.
title: When William Came
author: Saki, 1870-1916
